content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. <math alttext="N a H C O 3, solid, plus H 3 C 6 H 5 O 7, aqueous, reacts to produce N a H 2 C 6 H 5 O 7, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid, plus C O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>NaHCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mpadded><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>7</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>→</mo><msub><mi>NaH</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>7</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mpadded><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>l</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> A student conducts a calorimetry experiment in which solid baking soda, <math alttext="N a H C O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>NaHCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>, reacts with excess aqueous citric acid, <math alttext="H 3 C 6 H 5 O 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>7</mn></msub></math>, as represented by the equation above. The student places <math alttext="36.40 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>36.40</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> of the <math alttext="H 3 C 6 H 5 O 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>7</mn></msub></math> solution into a calorimeter and measures the temperature. After <math alttext="30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>30</mn></math> seconds, <math alttext="8.00 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>8.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> of <math alttext="N a H C O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>NaHCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> is added. The data are recorded in the following table and graph. Mass of <math alttext="H 3 C 6 H 5 O 7, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>7</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> <math alttext="36.40 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>36.40</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> Mass of <math alttext="N a H C O 3, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>NaHCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> <math alttext="8.00 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>8.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> Total mass of reaction mixture <math alttext="44.40 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>44.40</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> Initial temperature <math alttext="19.9 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>19.9</mn><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> Final temperature <math alttext="3.2 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>3.2</mn><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> (a) Calculate the magnitude of <math alttext="q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>q</mi></math>, in joules, for this mixture using the data in the table. Assume that the reaction mixture in the calorimeter has a specific heat capacity of <math alttext="4.22 joules per gram degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.22</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mo>/</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo>·</mo><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. <math alttext="N a H C O 3, solid, plus H 3 C 6 H 5 O 7, aqueous, reacts to produce N a H 2 C 6 H 5 O 7, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid, plus C O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>NaHCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mpadded><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>7</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>→</mo><msub><mi>NaH</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>7</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mpadded><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>l</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> A student conducts a calorimetry experiment in which solid baking soda, <math alttext="N a H C O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>NaHCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>, reacts with excess aqueous citric acid, <math alttext="H 3 C 6 H 5 O 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>7</mn></msub></math>, as represented by the equation above. The student places <math alttext="36.40 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>36.40</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> of the <math alttext="H 3 C 6 H 5 O 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>7</mn></msub></math> solution into a calorimeter and measures the temperature. After <math alttext="30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>30</mn></math> seconds, <math alttext="8.00 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>8.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> of <math alttext="N a H C O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>NaHCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> is added. The data are recorded in the following table and graph. Mass of <math alttext="H 3 C 6 H 5 O 7, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>7</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> <math alttext="36.40 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>36.40</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> Mass of <math alttext="N a H C O 3, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>NaHCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> <math alttext="8.00 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>8.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> Total mass of reaction mixture <math alttext="44.40 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>44.40</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> Initial temperature <math alttext="19.9 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>19.9</mn><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> Final temperature <math alttext="3.2 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>3.2</mn><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> (a) Calculate the magnitude of <math alttext="q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>q</mi></math>, in joules, for this mixture using the data in the table. Assume that the reaction mixture in the calorimeter has a specific heat capacity of <math alttext="4.22 joules per gram degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.22</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mo>/</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo>·</mo><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>.
(b) Based on the collisions that occur between particles, explain why the graph shows temperature changing less rapidly as time progresses in the experiment.
(c) Make a claim about the flow of heat between the reaction system and the surroundings during this experiment. The claim should be consistent with the data in the graph.

(d) The student conducts a second experiment using <math alttext="36.40 grams" overflow="scroll"> <mn>36.40</mn> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi> </math> of <math alttext="H 3 C 6 H 5 O 7, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>7</mn></msub><mfenced><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> at an initial temperature of <math alttext="19.9 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mn>19.9</mn><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>. However, the student adds only <math alttext="4.00 grams" overflow="scroll"> <mn>4.00</mn> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi> </math> of <math alttext="N a H C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>NaHCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>s</mi></mfenced></math>. Would the temperature change in the second experiment be greater than, less than, or equal to the temperature change in the first experiment? Justify your answer.

skill.text: 2.B: Formulate a hypothesis or predict the results of an experiment.
